## Introduction

In the previous [post](), we learnt about dplyr verbs and used them to compute average order value for an e-commerce website data. In this module, we will learn to combine tables using different `*_join` functions provided in dplyr. Let us assume we have 2 tables **x** and **y**. 

We will explore the following type of `joins` 

- inner join
- left join
- right join
- semi join
- anti join
- full join

<br>

## Libraries, Code & Data

We will use the [dplyr](http://dplyr.tidyverse.org/index.html) and [readr](http://readr.tidyverse.org/index.html) packages. The data sets can be downloaded from [here](https://github.com/rsquaredacademy/datasets) and the codes from [here](https://gist.github.com/aravindhebbali/3e31f13a4194a8f1003034aa7d70d5ee).

```{r dplyr1, message=FALSE}
library(dplyr)
library(readr)
options(tibble.width = Inf)
```

<br>

## Case Study

<br>

![](/img/join_data.png)

<br>

### Data: Orders

```{r dplyr2, message=FALSE}
order <- readr::read_csv('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rsquaredacademy/datasets/master/order.csv')
order
```

<br>

### Data: Customers

```{r dplyr, message=FALSE}
customer <- readr::read_csv('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rsquaredacademy/datasets/master/customer.csv')
customer
```

<br>

![](/img/join.png)

<br>

## inner join

<br>

![](/img/draw_inner.png)

<br>

```{r dplyr3}
customer %>%
  inner_join(order)
```

<br>

## left join

<br>

![](/img/draw_left.png)

<br>

```{r dplyr4}
customer %>%
  left_join(order)
```

<br>

## right join

<br>

![](/img/draw_right.png)

<br>

```{r dplyr5}
customer %>%
  right_join(order)
```

<br>

## semi join

<br>

![](/img/draw_semi.png)

<br>

```{r dplyr6}
customer %>%
  semi_join(order)
```

<br>

## anti join

<br>

![](/img/draw_anti.png)

<br>

```{r dplyr7}
customer %>%
  anti_join(order)
```

<br>

## full join

<br>

![](/img/draw_full.png)

<br>

```{r dplyr8}
customer %>%
  full_join(order)
```
